1. **Milk is nutritious,** Yes[1]. But in this day and age plant base milk sources are much better and simply more nutritious.[1]. One can completely avoid milk and get all the benefits of milk and much more from a simple balanced diet. (Completely irrelevant to the verse in the quran)

2. **Lactose Intolerance**. The main issue here is that fact that 68-70% of adults simply lack the enzymes necessary to digest milk and some diary products.[2]
Its a very common with Arabs today[3], and was the case even back then.[3]

3. **Hisorical health concerns.** The biggest and the most important problem is that the milk we drink today isn't the same as the the milk people drank back in the 7th century. Modern day milk is goes through lots of processing before its ready for consumption[4].
Different brands fortify their milk with different nutrients and added flavours. Pasteurization, an important process involved in making milk safe for humans by killing the bacteria wasn't invented until 1863. Raw milk is a playground for all sorts of bacteria and an source for many milk borne diseases[5].


Which brings me to my conclusion (I'm only using the 2nd and 3rd point as it makes the first one irrelevant):

*   **The Quran mentions no disadvantages to the consumption of milk. It encourages it as a remedy for "all illness except Death" despite the fact that milk itself contains bacterias that causes illness. Alcohol is *Haram* because it is *harmful* to humans, but milk is not?**
* **The Quran being the eternal speech of allah and for all humans, Couldn't foresee the fact that the majority of the world population would be Lactose Intolerant. Nor did it knew the fact that Lactose Intolerance existed in the 7th century.**
